_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
                                      for the
                       Caribbean Petroleum Refining, LP
                Bayamon Terminal ¿ Risk Management Plan


Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership is 99% owned subsidiary of Caribbean 
Petroleum Corporation.  Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership was formed in 
February of 1996 as part of a reorganization of the partnership.  Caribbean Petroleum 
Corporation under this reorganization transferred the terminal, the pipeline and terminal facilities 
to the Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership.

Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership enjoys a unique position on the island of 
Puerto Rico ¿ that of owning its own terminal but also owning its own chain of retail outlets across 
the island (approximately 215 service stations), owning an oil dock, and, having access to 
pipelines connecting the facility to the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority, the San Juan 
International Airport and all major marketers¿ bulk terminal facilities.

Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership does not currently operate the refinery located 
at this site and this is the greatest change from the previous RMP submission.  The tanks and 
bullets are used for wholesale bulk storage and distribution of the following hydrocarbon products;

     1. Regular gasoline.
     2. Premium gasoline.
     3. Number 6 fuel oil.
     4. Low sulfur diesel fuel.
     5. High sulfur diesel fuel.
     6. Jet fuel.
     7. Light distillate.
     8. HD5 ¿ high purity propane.

The facility does not currently produce or store butane at the terminal.  In August of 2000 the 
refinery ceased the processing of crude oil due to market conditions.  The refinery does not have 
an HF Alkylation unit nor does it use chlorine as a biocide at the cooling tower.  Toluene is not 
produced nor stored as a finished product and only exists as a minor component of the gasoline.  
Thus,

toluene is not reportable under RMP regulations.

As can be seen from the list of products above (stored in quantities greater than the threshold 
quantity of 10,000 Lbs.) and distributed by the terminal, propane is the flammable chemical of 
interest for RMP reporting.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the terminal.

Caribbean Petroleum Refining Limited Partnership has developed an overall safety and health 
policy to prevent accidental releases of flammable materials to the environment.  This policy is 
supported by many programs, such as, the compliance with OSHA¿s 1910.119 Process Safety 
Management regulation which includes the communication of risks and hazards to the employees 
and contractors, the development of an employee training and retraining program with written 
operating procedures.  Since the terminal is subject to the 29 CFR 1910.119 regulation, it 
qualifies as a Program 3 facility under the EPA¿s Risk Management Plan regulation.

The terminal management also stresses the development and documentation of the process 
safety information, the management of change procedure, pre-start up safety reviews and an 
equipment mechanical integrity inspection program for all major equipment items and piping 
systems, safety equipment, as well as, new equipment purchases.  The terminal operations 
personnel also issue hot work permits and cold work permits for maintenance activities in the 
areas where the various products are stored and transferred.

The terminal also conducts the following safety inspections on the basis as noted:

     1. Work areas ¿ weekly.
     2. Portable fire extinguishers ¿ monthly.
     3. Fire protection system ¿ every 2 months.
     4. Boilers ¿ annually (when operated).
     5. Pressure vessels ¿ every 5 years, or as required by API RP 510 (when operated).
     6. Extension chords, motorized hand tools ¿ every 3 months.
     7. Yards, parking lots, roofs, etc. ¿ annually.
     8. LPG storage ve

ssels ¿ annually.

In addition, incident investigations are initiated within 48 hours after any accidental release or 
incident occurs.  The root cause is determined and the appropriate steps are taken to prevent 
recurrence of the event.

The terminal also has an emergency response plan in the event of the accidental release of a 
flammable material.  There is an employee staffed emergency brigade which can be mobilized 
rapidly should a release occur and subsequently develop into a fire.  The following civil entities 
provide back-up support for the terminal emergency brigade:

     1. Bayamon Fire Department.
     2. Catano Fire Department.
     3. San Juan Fire Department.

In addition to the emergency brigade, the LPG truck loading station has two (2) fire monitors, as 
well as, four (4) area combustible gas detectors that alarm in the immediate area when a release 
of propane is detected.

The terminal engineering staff also follows and adheres to the guidelines set forth in American 
Petroleum Institute (API) standards, National Boiler Inspection Codes (NBIC) for fired boilers 
when operated, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) pressure vessel and 
piping codes, and the National Electric Codes for flammable environments.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.

Caribbean Petroleum Refining, LP has a long-standing commitment to the safety of the general 
public, of the terminal employees and to the preservation of the environment.  One primary 
portion of this commitment is the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances in 
and around the terminal.  Caribbean Petroleum Refining, LP has implemented numerous 
procedures to ensure the safety and well being of its employees and the general public, as well 
as, the environment outside of the fence line.  The process units and storage vessels have been 
inspected and repaired or rebuilt as necessary prior to the introduction of hydroca

rbons into the 
terminal for the start up in 1999.  During the period of December of 1998 and January 1999, the 
terminal staff performed a thorough pre-start up safety analysis of each unit using a HAZOP 
based methodology.  Since the refinery was shut down in 2000, the five (5) year revalidations will 
not be performed until prior to the next start-up of the refinery.

The terminal has a policy of conducting periodic mechanical integrity inspections, depending on 
the type of equipment and as based on the applicable American Petroleum Institute Codes and 
Recommended Practices.  The last mechanical integrity inspections of the propane bullets were 
conducted during the period of 1999 - 2000 per the API Code 510 and RP 572.  The next 
inspections are scheduled for the year 2010.

The terminal additionally has a facility-wide fire protection system with emphasis on the areas of 
the terminal where releases and subsequent fires are more likely to develop.  The fire protection 
equipment is tested on a periodic basis.  The fire protection system has two fire water pumps ¿ 
one driven by a gasoline engine and one driven by a diesel engine.  Firewater is stored in a tank 
with a capacity of 1,050,000 gallons of fresh water.

The terminal also operates and maintains a foam fire truck which is used to disperse a water and 
foam mixture on existing fires or on released flammable liquids to prevent their ignition.

The propane bullets are specifically protected by deluge systems that are remotely and manually 
operated in event of a fire.

The five year accident history.

With the fact in mind that the refinery was shut down in August of 2000, there has been only one 
release of flammable materials in the propane storage and handling area.  This happened on 
March 31, 2004, during a truck unloading process where the operator had given the instruction to 
a propane truck driver to begin unloading.  The truck pump discharge was inadvertently lined up 
to a nearly full storage

tank.  This caused the overfilling of the tank and subsequent discharge of 
liquid and vaporous propane from the relief valve on the tank for approximately 15 minutes.  
Fortunately, the flammable gas did not ignite and the facility did not experience a vapor cloud 
explosion.  The operating procedures were revised to prevent recurrence.  

The emergency response program.

The Caribbean Petroleum Refining, LP emergency response plan is designed to address the 
terminal¿s main hazard ¿ the hazard of fires and/or explosions.  The response plan covers office 
building fires specifically during working hours on weekdays, weekends and holidays.  The 
responsibilities for various functions during the emergency are clearly defined in the response 
plan.  Gathering places for employees evacuated from the office building by the fire are also 
listed, as well as, methods to account for all employees.

The emergency response plan also addresses fires that occur in the terminal away from office 
buildings.  The response plan contains reporting procedures for employees when the fire is too 
large to be extinguished with a portable, handheld fire extinguisher.  At that point the fire alarm is 
communicated via radio by the security guard at the front gate which mobilizes the shift 
supervisor and the company staffed emergency brigade.  The emergency coordinator and/or his 
alternate assess the situation and decide whether to call for additional fire fighting assistance (the 
local fire departments listed above) and whether to call for a total or partial evacuation of the 
terminal.

A Command Center is established where key personnel summoned by the emergency 
coordinator will direct the emergency response efforts.  The emergency brigade reports to the 
security building and prepares to fight the fire.  Access to the terminal is tightly controlled by the 
security guard at the gate.  All visitors are escorted to safety by the employee in charge of the 
visitor.  Fire fighting ef

forts are coordinated with any local fire fighting departments if they have 
been called.  The Shift Supervisor and emergency brigade advise and work with them to control 
the situation.

In order to maintain the necessary skills, the emergency brigade practices fire fighting techniques 
on a semi-annual basis.  Fire drills (announced and unannounced) in the plant are held at a 
frequency of two (2) drills per year.

Planned changes for improved safety.

The Caribbean Petroleum Refining, LP personnel constantly strive to improve the safety of it 
operations through periodic safety reviews, the incident investigation program and a program 
soliciting safety suggestions from the employees.  Any proposed changes to the current operating 
modes for propane would trigger the Management of Change procedure, as well as, the PHA, 
PSSR, PSI, Employee Participation elements of the RMP.
